comment.author: 12220922@N05
comment._content: Being able to see evocative photographs such as this, taken in emotional times when history really was in the making, makes me appreciate more than ever the immense and irreplaceable value of photography, and of the National Library's archive. This is an outstanding image, not least because it's immediate and unposed... and the subjects, of course, are of profound importance to Ireland's history. Utterly beyond value - and a joy to view, nearly 90 years later.

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Well Taken. Grief for families world wide is to lose a Soldier at war.

comment.author: 69699465@N00
comment._content:
This is a superb and historic picture, especially given its proximity to Collins' death. As an Englishman who's lived extensively in Ireland, absorbed a lot of the Easter Rising legend and mythology at first hand (I had ancient neighbours in Clare who were DeValera men from their earliest youth), yet who also was an English consumer of the Thatcher doctrine of "no oxygen of publicity for terrorists" (aka total denial of any argument or debate in a public arena) in the 70s/80s, I find Collins especially fascinating. The widely acknowledged inventor of "modern" terror warfare, non-uniformed guerrilla tactics where the participants simply disappear, yet the same man who went knowingly to his eventual death signing a compromise treaty he knew pragmatically was the best he could hope for at the time, but would not satisfy many of those who'd stood beside him. 

Irish history and the troubled relationship with Britain, and the personalities of those who made it should be better known, thought about and understood. So many on every side of the argument take simplistic views, but it's so hugely complex. 

Sorry for waffling!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/stevefe] That's not waffle, Steve! Thank you for such a thoughtful comment.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69699465@N00
comment._content:
I've heard Dev vs Collins at first hand from so many Irish friends, and read the literature from both sides, and it's still so hard to call. Could Big Mick have been the great Irish leader that Dev tried to be yet somehow fell just that bit short of? Who knows?

History would have been different had Collins lived, that's all we can say.
